data.title: Best Yankees center fielder: Joe DiMaggio or Mickey Mantle? There’s no wrong answer
authors: Mike Rosenstein | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
data.meta_description: Joe DiMaggio's final season on the New York Yankees was in 1951, when he played alongside Mickey Mantle, a rookie outfielder who was the heir apparent in center.
data.text:
To help pass the time during the coronavirus pandemic, MLB.com has been engaging fans to debate the wait by ranking the top players at each position on each club.

So far, we’ve gone through the Yankees’ catchers, first basemen, second basemen, third basemen, shortstops and left fielders.

Up next could be the biggest debate of them all: center field. Joe DiMaggio vs. Mickey Mantle. Legions of fans have been arguing about this for decades. MLB.com adds to the discussion with its two cents.

1. Mickey Mantle (1951-68)

20-time All-Star, 7-time World Series champion, 3-time American League MVP, 1974 Hall of Fame inductee

Mantle won the 1956 Triple Crown, hitting 52 home runs with a career-high 130 RBI and a .353 batting average (it would be Mantle’s only batting title).

In 18 years, he hit .298 with 536 home runs, which ranks 18th all-time.

2. Joe DiMaggio (1936-51)

13-time All-Star, 9-time World Series champion, 3-time American League MVP, 1955 Hall of Fame Inductee

DiMaggio’s 56-game hitting streak in 1941 stands as one of the untouchable records in baseball. He missed the 1943-45 seasons while serving in the military during World War II.

DiMaggio was a lifetime .325 hitter, winning a pair of batting titles in 1939 (.381) and 1940 (.352).

3. Bernie Williams (1991-2006)

5-time All-Star, 4-time World Series champion

Williams also won four Gold Gloves as the center fielder for the Yankees’ most recent dynasty. He won a batting title in 1998, hitting .339.

4. Earle Combs (1924-35)

3-time World Series champion, 1970 Hall of Fame inductee

Combs played 12 seasons, all with the Yankees, and was a key cog atop the Murderers’ Row lineup with Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig.

5. Bobby Murcer (1965-74, 1979-83)

5-time All-Star

Murcer had two tours with the Yankees, but missed the World Series titles in 1977 and 1978. The Gold Glover winner finished in the top 9 of MVP voting three times.
